Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 54379-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2020 
 
 
Capacity Building for Project Implementation in 
South Asia 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CDRC  –  Capacity Development Resource Center 
  COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  SARD  –  South Asia Department 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  Shixin Chen, Operations 1 
Director General  Kenichi Yokoyama, Director General, South Asia Department 
(SARD) 
Deputy Director General  Diwesh Sharan, Deputy Director General, SARD 
Advisor  Eleonora Windisch; Portfolio, Results, and Quality Control Unit at 
the Office of the Director General (SAOD-PR); SARD 
Team leader  Jazira Asanova, Principal Operations Coordination Specialist, 
Office of the Director General (SAOD), SARD 
Team members  Chris Cruz-Roxas, Senior Operations Coordination Officer, SAOD, 
SARD 
  Joana Custoias, Counsel, Office of the General Counsel 
Maria Angela Malihan, Senior Operations Assistant, Regional 
Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division, SARD 
Francesco Tornieri, Principal Social Development Specialist 
(Gender and Development), SAOD-PR, SARD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The regional knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support capacity 
development of developing member countries (DMCs) in South Asia by consolidating and further 
strengthening the institutional approach for delivering capacity building programs in the South 
Asia Department (SARD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The TA will upgrade and digitize 
capacity building programs on ADB procedures, including financial management, procurement 
and  contract  management,  disbursement,  gender,  safeguards,  and  project  monitoring  and 
reporting for virtual delivery; and develop detailed training programs tailored to DMC demand and 
emerging issues and aligned with best practices in course design and delivery.1 
 
2.  The TA is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priority 6 on strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity, particularly on strengthening government capacity to plan, 
design, finance, and implement ADB projects; operational priority 1 on addressing remaining 
poverty and reducing inequalities; and operational priority 2 on accelerating progress in gender 
equality,2 as strengthened DMC capacity to implement ADB-funded projects would help achieve 
development outcomes in government- and ADB-funded projects. The TA is aligned with ADB’s 
country programs for SARD DMCs, as they put a premium on strengthening the performance of 
ADB-financed projects to achieve development outcomes. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Alignment with the Asian Development Bank strategy. The TA is aligned with ADB’s 
Strategy 2030, including its focus on strengthening the capacity of executing and implementing 
agencies  to  implement  ADB-financed  projects.  In  2010,  SARD  introduced  the  Capacity 
Development Resource Center (CDRC) in the India Resident Mission to provide structured and 
systematic development of government agencies' capacity to implement ADB-funded projects. 
CDRC has played a significant role in strengthening portfolio performance through training in ADB 
procedures, project implementation, and thematic areas. Since CDRC’s introduction, 10,600 
executing and implementing agency staff have received training in ADB procedures and thematic 
areas, contributing to improved portfolio performance. The India Resident Mission’s capacity 
development model was successfully replicated in the Nepal Resident Mission starting in 2015, 
and SARD’s other resident missions have been delivering training in their DMCs. 
 
4.  Upgrading the quality of capacity building. The SARD portfolio’s rapid growth has led 
to many executing and implementing agencies, in new sectors and remote areas, implementing 
ADB-financed projects. Emerging needs, the increasing complexity and multisector approaches 
of ADB projects, and the evolving development landscape require ADB to scale up and upgrade 
capacity development initiatives. There is a need to (i) develop a common framework for capacity 
development in SARD DMCs, (ii) mainstream the CDRC model to other SARD resident missions, 
and (iii) upgrade CDRC capacity to deliver courses. In early 2020, SARD launched the CDRC 
network, comprising SARD resident mission staff, to develop the common framework that will help 
create economies of scale, improve efficiency, and ensure consistency of capacity development 
activities.  The  framework  aims  to  standardize  content  and  delivery,  provide  guidance  and 
technology support to resident missions, and foster collaboration. 
 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 10 November 2020. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.

2 
5.  SARD resident missions deliver training using their own training materials, which are of 
varying quality. Updating materials in each SARD resident mission because of changes in ADB 
policies and procedures often results in duplication of efforts. There is a need to develop a 
standard set of training materials applicable to all resident missions, while recognizing the unique 
context of each SARD DMC and tailoring these courses to local contexts. Developing and 
strengthening executing and implementing agency staff capacity to implement ADB-financed 
projects requires not only increasing their understanding of ADB policies and procedures but also 
developing specific skills that would lead to strong portfolio performance. Therefore, CDRC needs 
to develop modular, competency-based, and interactive training courses for DMCs. Competency-
based training requires analyzing the job tasks that executing and implementing agencies are 
expected to perform in procurement, financial management, and other related areas. The task 
analysis results will help provide a solid foundation for upgrading the capacity building programs. 
 
6.  Review of CDRC courses in May 2020 recommended the following improvements:3 (i) 
improve audience targeting; (ii) implement competency-based training, focusing on expected 
competencies by conducting a task analysis to identify required knowledge, skills, and attitudes; 
(iii) translate overall course goals into more specific learning outcomes; (iv) classify CDRC 
courses according to complexity and prepare guidelines for developing a learning road map for 
executing agencies; (v) use a varied approach to content delivery to engage participants actively 
and make courses more practical and applied; (vi) make the courses accessible by putting them 
online; (vii) improve course module structure and relevance to executing and implementing 
agencies; and (viii) improve learning transfer and retention. In addition, the review highlighted the 
need to create a support network for executing and implementing agencies to enhance their 
learning, measure the impact of training on portfolio performance, offer more clinic-type capacity 
building,4 and develop and launch courses to meet the emerging needs of  executing and 
implementing agencies. 
 
7.  Converting training to digital. In light of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, 
most capacity building programs for SARD DMCs have shifted to virtual training, which has given 
the impetus to harness the power of technology. To this end, the TA will (i) convert core CDRC 
courses into virtual training, (ii) train resource persons and facilitators in designing and facilitating 
virtual training and interactive delivery, (iii) develop detailed guidelines for instructional design and 
delivery, (iv) assess technology infrastructure availability at executing and implementing agencies 
and propose hardware and connectivity solutions for those in remote locations, (v) enhance online 
registration and nomination systems, (vi) assess options for web-based clinics for executing and 
implementing agencies, and (vii) develop an online repository of frequently asked questions. 
 
8.  Strengthening the sustainability of capacity development. Sustainable Development 
Goal 17.9 focuses on enhancing “international support for implementing effective and targeted 
capacity-building in developing countries,”5 including cooperation among DMCs. Therefore, DMC 
capacity needs to be systematically strengthened to design and implement development projects. 
An integrated approach that leads to an incrementally institutionalized framework is needed to 
ensure sustainability of the DMC capacity building. To maximize resources and build local 
capacity, CDRC focuses on a strategy of engaging national training organizations to co-deliver 
capacity building under CDRC with ADB staff. 
 
 
3  The review was undertaken under ADB. India: Capacity Building for Project Design, Implementation and Evaluation. 
4  Clinics refer to targeted project group work where trainers and participant teams work together on advanced topics 
related to project design and implementation. 
5  United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs. Goal 17.

3 
9.  The India Resident Mission has leveraged partnerships with national training institutes to 
support various aspects of training, and the Nepal Resident Mission has partnered with the Nepal 
Administrative  Staff  College  to  co-deliver  training.  For  enhanced  sustainability,  training 
partnerships may need to be maximized beyond providing logistical support to include training 
administration, new course development, training delivery, and training assessment. Therefore, 
the TA will support efforts to institutionalize capacity building by identifying successful models 
from international financing institutions for engaging national training institutes in DMC capacity 
building, identifying ways of cost sharing between ADB and national training institutes, and linking 
CDRC training to government civil servant certification systems.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: operational effectiveness of ADB projects in 
South Asia enhanced. The TA will have the following outcome: capacity of executing and 
implementing agencies to design and implement ADB-financed projects in South Asia increased.6 
The outcome indicator of 1,000 executing and implementing agency staff under ADB-financed 
projects reporting improved knowledge and skills in ADB procedures by 2023 directly measures 
the expected outcome. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  The TA aims to consolidate and further strengthen the institutional approach for delivering 
capacity  development  programs.  As  part  of  the  CDRC  common  framework,  the  TA  will 
progressively introduce materials and instruments, including developing modular competency-
based tailored training to executing and implementing agencies with different capacity and 
fostering knowledge sharing among DMCs and cross-learning on flagship investment projects 
and good practices. The TA outputs will support strengthening instructional design and delivery 
where training materials and activities will be elaborated and revised for interactivity, meaningfully 
sequenced, and enriched by smart tutorial components and quality assurance mechanisms, 
including pre- and post-training support. 
 
12.  Output 1: Capacity building programs upgraded. Output 1 will support the following: 
 
(i)  The TA will engage experienced instructional designers and e-learning experts to 
convert at least five CDRC courses to virtual training using videos, online polls and 
quizzes, interactive group work, and an online repository of learning materials. The 
courses will be converted in coordination with ADB departments, such as the 
Controller’s Department; the Procurement, Portfolio, and Financial Management 
Department; and the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department; 
and tailored to local contexts in coordination with SARD resident missions. CDRC 
digital  content  will  be  uploaded  and  accessible  by  external  users,  such  as 
executing and implementing agencies. In addition, frequently asked questions for 
key content areas will be developed and shared through an online repository. 
 
(ii)  At least one CDRC course will be redesigned as a modular, competency-based 
training course with job task analysis. The TA will support developing a standard 
training  approach  and  format  (a  training  package  consisting  of  a  syllabus, 
 
6  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
presentation slides, case studies, and delivery mechanisms), aligned with the 
principles and best practices of adult learning, in addition to a pilot executing and 
implementing agency capacity rating approach for the redesigned CDRC course. 
 
(iii)  At least 10 capacity building events, including peer learning and regional learning 
events using upgraded materials, will be conducted. The TA will provide training 
for resource persons and facilitators in participatory techniques and interactive 
virtual delivery. 
 
13.  Output 2: Digital solutions developed. Output 2 will support (i) updating an online 
course registration and nomination system, (ii) assessing the technology infrastructure of remotely 
located  executing  and  implementing  agencies  and  recommending  hardware  and  software 
solutions for connectivity issues, (iii) developing an online searchable repository of frequently 
asked questions, and (iv) developing options for web-based clinic sessions for executing and 
implementing agencies. 
 
14.  Output 3: Sustainability of capacity building developed. The TA will develop proposals 
to engage accredited national training institutions to deliver training in partnership with ADB 
resident mission staff. This output will involve identifying (i) successful models for engaging 
national training institutes in multilateral development bank capacity building, (ii) ways of cost 
sharing between ADB and national training institutes, and (iii) successful multilateral development 
bank projects that support capacity building of DMC governments’ civil servants and link them to 
governments’ own certification systems. 
 
15.  Knowledge generated by the TA will include practice guides, frequently asked questions 
for executing and implementing agencies, DMC knowledge sharing events, and digitized courses 
that will be available to executing and implementing agencies even after the training events. 
Strengthening DMC capacity for implementing ADB-financed projects requires going beyond 
classroom training and increasing support for executing and implementing agency staff after 
training events to build their confidence in applying what they have learned. The TA will develop 
proposals for web-based clinics and coaching for executing and implementing agencies and will 
organize knowledge exchange and cross-learning activities, such as peer learning. 
 
16.  CDRC will adopt an integrated approach to capacity building. The TA aims to make the 
CDRC courses, including those offered by other ADB departments, part of a learning journey 
rather than a one-time event. This requires enhanced coordination with ADB stakeholders to 
ensure that the capacity building initiatives build on each other. ADB’s value addition includes 
assessing digital solutions such as web-based clinics and evaluating options for enhancing the 
sustainability of DMC capacity building initiatives by linking CDRC training to government civil 
servant certification systems. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $300,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will administer the TA. SARD will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; 
organize workshops; and provide staff to act as resource persons in the workshops.

5 
 
19.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

Source: ADB estimates. 
 
20.  Consulting services. The TA will require international and national consulting services 
from  firms  and  individuals  in  fields  relevant  to  capacity  development.  The  TA  will  finance 
consulting  services,  experts’  meetings  and  workshops,  and  training  preparation.  Resource 
persons will be engaged, as needed, to provide qualitative and quantitative inputs supporting TA 
activities and outputs. Output-based or lump-sum contracts, indefinite contracts, or framework 
agreements for consulting services will be considered as applicable. ADB will engage consultants 
following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.7 Consultants will be mobilized virtually 
and produce deliverables using virtual collaboration tools given international travel restrictions 
related to COVID-19 and taking into account the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis for 
Capacity Building for Project Implementation in South Asia, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board. 
 
7  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
